questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following acts as the primary trigger for onset of labour in pregnant women?
questions.explanation:
The fetal ACTH causes an increase in estrogen acting as the onset of labour in pregnant women. It 
results in the growth of the fetal adrenal gland which has the capacity for steroid biosynthesis i.e. 
estrogen. Daily steroid production of fetal adrenal glands near term is more than in adults.

questions.question:
Question 2: All of the following changes are seen during cervical ripening in a patient except  
.
questions.explanation:
Collagen fibrils are loosely packed during cervical ripening. Changes in cervical ripening: • Collagen fibril diameter is increased, and there is increased spacing between fibrils leading 
to increased tissue compliance • Increase in the amount of proteoglycan and glycosaminoglycan within the matrix • Stromal invasion with inflammatory cells

questions.question:
Question 3: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. What is the 
reflex elicited in the process? 177 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Stripping of membranes is depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. Fetal ejection reflex or Ferguson reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the 
internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has been 
suggested but not proven. It is seen in stripping/sweeping and artificial rupture of membranes. Both of these are methods of 
induction of labor. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of 
prostaglandin F2 metabolite, also known as dinoprost/carboprost. 188 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following image shows the Duncan method?
questions.explanation:
Image B shows the Duncan method of placental separation. Comparison between two types of placental separation methods: Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta 
from the uterus in the third stage of labour. One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fi 
ngers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwar 
ds and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord. Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the 
placenta covers the internal os partially i.e. it covers the internal os when closed but does not 
entirely do so when fully dilated. Schultze method 
Duncan method Separation begins from the p 
eriphery to the center. Separation begins from the c 
enter of the placenta to the p 
eriphery. Blood does not escape extern 
ally, as the blood pours into t 
he membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagin 
a as the blood collects betwee 
n the membranes and the ute 
rine wall.

Question 5: In which stage of labour, is the following expelled? 178 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The placenta and membranes are expelled in the third stage of labour. 189

questions.explanation:
The encirclement of the largest head diameter by the vulval ring is called crowning. This occurs in 
the second stage of labour. First stage of labour is divided into 2 phases: Latent phase

questions.question: Question 7: What does fetal position refer to?

options.a: Part of presentation which lies over the internal os
options.b: Relation of different parts of fetus to one another
options.c: Relation of the denominator to different quadrants of the pelvis
options.d: Part of fetus lying in the lower segment of uterus

questions.explanation:
Fetal position refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to 
different quadrants of the pelvis. Definition of various terminologies used for fetus in-utero: Term:

questions.question:
Question 8: A senior resident examines a primigravida in labour and informs that the fetus is cephalic in 
attitude of flexion. What is the most common presenting part of this fetus?
questions.explanation:
The most common presenting part when the fetus is in attitude of flexion is vertex. Attitude 
Presenting part Complete flexion 
Vertex (occipitoanterior) Incomplete flexio 
n Vertex (sinciput) Deflexion 
Vertex (occipitoposterior) Partial extension 
Brow Complete extensi 
on Face 191 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: The ultrasonogram shows the diameter of the fetal head which is taken as a reference for 
engagement. Which diameter does this refer to?
questions.explanation:
The fetal head is said to be engaged when the biparietal diameter (shown in the image) passes 
through the pelvic brim. Engagement of fetal head is with reference to this biparietal diameter. It is the greatest transverse diameter in an occiput presentation. It also reflects the gestational age 
in the second trimester, with a variation of 7-10 days. BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum 
pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner 
edge of the skull in the far field. 192 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not a part of a partograph?
questions.explanation: Fetal temperature is not a part of a partograph. Assessment of progress of labor is best done by partograph. Components of partograph: • Patient identification • Fetal heart rate recorded every 30 min • Pulse recorded every 30 min • Blood pressure and temperature recorded every 4 h • Uterine contractions recorded every 30 min • Oxytocin-dose and concentration • Urine analysis • Vaginal examination done every 4 hours • State of membranes and colour of liquor

questions.question: Question 11: What are the cardinal movements of labour?
questions.explanation:
The cardinal movements of labour are engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension, 
external rotation, expulsion. (Mnemonic: Every Day FIRE Raises Extremely) • Every: Engagement • Day: Descent • F: Flexion • IR: Internal rotation • E: Extension • Raises: external Rotation • Extremely: Expulsion The most common presentation is cephalic and presenting part is vertex. Head enters the pelvis 
through transverse diameter majorly and left occipito transverse is the commonest fetal position. 
Internal rotation of fetal head occurs at the level of ischial spine. In a vertex delivery, the baby's 
head is delivered by extension and in a breech delivery, the baby's head is delivered by flexion. 
The best time to give episotomy is after crowning has occured. 193 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A multigravida with gestational diabetes mellitus was admitted in labour at term and 
progressed to full dilatation. The fetal vertex failed to descend beyond -3 station. The descent 
of the fetus is facilitated by all except:

options.a: Extension and straightening of the fetal body

questions.explanation: A well-flexed head facilitates internal rotation, not the descent of the presenting part. The descent of the fetus is brought about by: • Pressure of amniotic fluid • Direct pressure of the fundus upon the breech with contractions • Bearing-down efforts of maternal abdominal muscles • Extension and straightening of the fetal body

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the fetal head for a woman in 
labor?
questions.explanation: The tone of levator ani muscles is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the head. Prerequisites of internal rotation of the head are as follows: • Well-flexed head • Efficient uterine contraction • Favorable shape at mid-pelvic plane • Tone of the levator ani muscles

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following statements is true regarding the internal rotation of the fetal head? 181 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Occiput turns towards the transverse axis
options.b: Rotation is not essential when the fetus is unusually small
options.c: Internal rotation is followed by external rotation
options.d: Rotation is earlier in primigravida than in multigravida

questions.explanation:
Internal rotation is not essential in the completion of labor when the fetus is unusually small. 194 
Sold by @itachibot Internal rotation begins with the occiput turning away from the transverse axis. In 
majority, internal rotation is completed by the time the head reaches the pelvic floor. Internal 
rotation is followed by extension of the head, which is then followed by external rotation. Rotation occurs earlier in multigravida than primigravida whereas engagement occurs earlier in 
primigravida than multigravida.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the minimum rate of cervical dilatation in primigravida during active labour?
questions.explanation:
During active labor, the minimal rate of cervical dilatation in primigravida is 1.2 cm/hr. First stage of labour is divided into 2 phases: The cervical dilatation ranges from a minimal rate of 1.2 cm - 6.8 cm/hr in nullipara. Also, the 
multiparas progress faster in the active phase of labor with a minimal dilatation rate of 1.5 cm/hr. Friedman curve is the sigmoid curve plotting the pattern of cervical dilatation during the latent 
and active phase of normal labour. Latent phase 
Active phase Starts from  6 cm cervical di 
latation with regular uterine 
contractions The onset of true labor pain

multipara) The minimum rate of cervical 
dilatation:1.2 cm/h (nullipar 
a)1.5 cm/h (multipara) Concerned with cervicaldilata 
tion Concerned with cervicaleffac 
ement 195 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage of 
labor?

options.b: Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
options.c: Never give warm compress to the perineum

questions.explanation:
The practice of guarding the perineum during delivery of the fetal head is part of the WHO 
management guidelines for the second stage of labor. The fingers of one hand support the perineum, while the second hand applies pressure to the fetal 
head to control the speed of crowning. The advantage of this is to prevent perineal tears. The second stage of labor begins with full dilatation of the cervix and ends with the delivery of the 
fetus. The main events include the descent of the fetus (bearing down by the mother, uterine 
contractions), cardinal movements of labor, and delivery of the fetus. Management of the second stage of labor: • The most common position used is the dorsal position with the hips flexed, knees flexed and 
abduction of the thighs. WHO recommends any position of choice including the upright position. • WHO recommendations for the prevention of perineal tears include warm compresses to the 
perineum, perineal massage, guarding the perineum, and modified Ritgen's maneuver. • Modified Ritgen's maneuver: A sterile towel or pad is held in one hand and placed over the 
perineum; the other hand applies gentle downward pressure on the occiput to promote flexion 
and controlled delivery of the head (ensuring the smallest diameter of the head passes through the 
outlet). Once the occiput is born–with gentle pressure, the head is extended–forehead, nose, and 
mouth are then delivered. • WHO doesn't recommend fundal pressure and routine episiotomy. Other options: Option A: A liberal or routine episiotomy is discouraged. Episiotomy is indicated in cases of: • Shoulder dystocia • Breech delivery • Fetal macrosomia • Operative vaginal deliveries • Persistent occiput posterior positions Option C: Manual techniques, such as massage or application of warm compresses, are 
recommended for healthy pregnant women requesting pain relief during labor. Option D: The position that is most comfortable to the mother i.e. upright/squatting position is 
encouraged. This position gives: • less discomfort and difficulty in bearing down • less labor pain • less perineal/vaginal trauma and wound infections Second stage 
Nulliparous 
Multiparous Mean/average duration 
50 minutes 
30 minutes Maximum duration 
2 hours (+1 with epidural) 
1 hour (+1 with epidural) 196 
Sold by @itachibot Second stage 
Nulliparous 
Multiparous 3 hours 
2 hours WHO maximum duration of 
2nd stage/diagnosis of arrest

questions.question: Question 17: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes:

options.c: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
options.d: Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.explanation:
Class 1 of modified Robson's classification includes nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, 
cephalic, spontaneous labor. It is the most widely accepted classification system available for analyzing characteristics of 
delivering women worldwide. It consists of 10 patient population categories. The basis for these 
categories include: • Parity • Onset of labor and mode of delivery • Gestational age • Fetal presentation • No. of fetuses The modified Robson system classification is as follows: Class

questions.question:
Question 18: Identify the fetal position in the given image. 182 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In the given vertex presentation, the fetal position is right occipitoanterior. Fetal position refers to the relation of the denominator (arbitrary bony fixed point on the 
presenting part), with respect to different quadrants of the maternal pelvis. In vertex presentation, 
the denominator is taken as the occiput (which is close to the triangular posterior fontanelle). To determine the fetal position the following two steps are followed: • Determine the direction in which the occiput is facing: • Towards the pubic symphysis - occipito-anterior • Towards the sacral promontory - occipito-posterior • Midway between pubic symphysis and sacral promontory - occipito-transverse • Determine if the occiput is facing the left or the right in relation to the materal pelvis

questions.question: Question 19: Uterine contractions are palpable when its intensity is more than     .
questions.explanation:
Uterine contractions are palpable when the intensity is >10 mmHg. 198 
Sold by @itachibot Uterine contractions cause cervical dilatation at 15 mmHg and are painful beyond 15 mmHg. Units for measuring the intensity of uterine contractions are mmHg and Montevideo units (MV). 1 MV = intensity of uterine contractions x number of contractions in 10 min. During labour, normal uterine contractions are between 190 and 300 MV and at the time of 
delivery, it is 300 MV. Pressure Stage of labou 
r 1st 
40–50 m 
mHg 2nd 
100–120 
mmHg 3rd 
100–120 
mmHg

questions.question:
Question 20: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, you 
notice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be 
used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.explanation:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor. This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the 
vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to 
exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts 
pressure superiorly against the occiput. This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.question: Question 21: Which dermatome is pain in the early stage of labor limited to?
questions.explanation:
199 
Sold by @itachibot Pain in the early stage of labor is limited to dermatomes T10-L1. This is of uterine origin. Pain in the late stage of labour is due to dilatation of cervix and perineal stretching. The nerves 
carrying the pain include S2,3,4.

questions.question:
Question 22: A young primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presented to the casualty crying of intense 
abdominal pain. She was diagnosed to be in labour. Which of the following is not a 
characteristic of this pain?
questions.explanation:
True labor pain is not relieved by enema and sedatives. It is characterized by the following: • Painful uterine contractions at regular intervals • The frequency of contractions increases gradually • The intensity and duration of contractions increase progressively • Associated with 'show'- extrusion of the mucus plug that had previously filled the cervical canal 
during pregnancy • Progressive effacement and dilatation of the cervix • Progressive descent of the presenting part • Formation of the 'bag of forewaters' i.e., bulging fluid-filled amniotic membrane presenting in 
front of the fetal head • Not relieved by enema or sedatives False labour pain is seen more in primigravidae than in parous women. It usually appears prior to 
the onset of true labor pain by 1 or 2 weeks in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae. Such pains are probably due to stretching of the cervix and lower uterine segment with 
consequent irritation of the neighboring ganglia. Features 
True labour pains 
False labour pain 
s Cervical dilatation and efface 
ment Present 
Absent Lower abdomen 
only Pain 
Lower abdomen and back, ra 
diating to thighs Show

questions.question:
Question 23: You notice the gynecology resident administer the nerve block seen in the image before 
performing an episiotomy. Which nerve roots are blocked? 184 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The nerve roots blocked in pudendal nerve block are S2,3,4. It is blocked just above the tip of 
the ischial spine by piercing the sacrospinous ligament. 200 
Sold by @itachibot Pudendal nerve block can be used for: • Analgesia in the second stage of labor • Episiotomy repair • Pelvic floor relaxation for outlet instrument delivery • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum • Perineal analgesia prior to application of vacuum/forceps Pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina. It is ineffective for pain relief 
associated with uterine manipulation such as manual extraction of the placenta.

questions.question: Question 24: Paracervical block relieves pain from all except:
questions.explanation:
Pain from the lower third of the vagina is relieved by pudendal block, not paracervical block. Paracervical block relieves the pain of uterine contractions and cervical dilatation. It also relieves 
pain from upper third of the vagina. It is not useful at the time of episiotomy as the lower part of 
the vagina is not anesthetized. Note: Paracervical block is no longer considered safe as it causes fetal bradycardia. Epidural 
analgesia is preferred when complete relief of pain is needed throughout labour.

questions.question: Question 25: All of the following are indications for early clamping of cord in a new born baby except:
questions.explanation:
Postdated pregnancy is not an indication for early cord clamping. Early cord clamping is indicated in: • Birth asphyxia • Rh isoimmunization • Diabetic mother The benefits of delayed cord clamping for up to 60 seconds is an increase in total body iron stores, 
expand blood volume and a decrease in anemia incidence in the neonate. On the other hand, delayed cord clamping can lead to a higher hemoglobin concentration, which 
increases risks for hyperbilirubinemia and extended hospitalization for neonatal phototherapy. 
Delayed cord clamping can also hinder timely neonatal resuscitation. According to AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology, in uncomplicated preterm birth, delayed cord 
clamping should be attempted. This is done for a minimum time of 60 seconds after delivery for 
preterm infants not requiring immediate resuscitation after birth. It states that DCC must be done 
even if the mother has an HIV infection. But as per the NACO guidelines, early cord clamping is 
advised. 201 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 26: Which of the following is not a sign of placental separation in stage 3 of parturition of a 
pregnant woman?
questions.explanation:
Lengthening of the umbilical cord is seen in placental separation. Signs of placental separation: • The uterus becomes globular, firm, and ballottable (earliest sign to appear) • Schroeder's sign - Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower 
segment and uterus rests over it • Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment. • Kustner's sign - On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no 
longer recedes • A sudden gush of blood • Permanent lengthening of cord Note: Schroeder's ring is a constriction ring/contraction ring formed due to incoordinate uterine 
action.

questions.question:
Question 27: Which of the following is false regarding the modified WHO partogram? 185 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
options.b: Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
options.c: Each small square in partogram is equal to 1 hour
options.d: Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.explanation:
Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square in 
a composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.

questions.question: Question 28: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics.
questions.explanation:
The instrument given in the picture is episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is to 
prevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries / 
complete perineal tears. Complications of episiotomy: They can be immediate or remote. Immediate complications include an extension of the incision into the rectum, vulval hematoma, 
wound dehiscence and injury to anal sphincter. Remote complications include dyspareunia, chances of perineal lacerations in subsequent labor 
and scar endometriosis (rare). Mayo scissors are long and stout scissors. They can be blunt-tipped/pointed tip/straight or curved. 
Straight mayo scissors are designed for cutting body tissues near the surface of a wound. They are 
also used to cut sutures and are also known as suture-cutting scissors. Curved mayo scissors allow much deeper penetration into the wound and are used to cut thick 
tissues such as those found in the uterus, muscles, breast, and foot. Mayo scissors used for 
dissection are placed in tissue with the tips closed. The scissors are then opened so that the tips 
open and spread out the tissue during the dissection process. 202 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 29: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to monitor the progress of 
labour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, should she start the documentation?

options.b: It is common in nulliparous labour
options.d: Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.explanation:
The WHO Labour Care Guide begins the documentation of labour progression at 5 cm of cervical 
dilatation. The WHO Labour Care Guide is a tool designed to help health personnel involved in labour care. 
It aims to • Guide the monitoring and help in the documentation of the progress of labour. • Guide the health professionals to offer supportive care throughout labour. • Assist doctors in promptly identifying and addressing emerging labour complications. • Prevent the use of unnecessary interventions in labour. • Support audits and quality improvement. 203 
Sold by @itachibot The differences between the WHO-modified partograph and the latest WHO Labour Care Guide 
are tabulated below: Note: Previously the answer to the question was 4 cm (according to the modified WHO 
patograph). However, this information is outdated, therefore the answer to this question has been 
revised per the latest WHO guidelines. WHO modified partograph
